definitions: The tiny building block of matter, the basic unit of a chemical element
Made up of protons, neutrons, and electrons
A group of atoms joined together
The smallest unit of a chemical compound that can exist independently
A substance made of only one type of atom
Cannot be broken down into simpler substances
A substance formed when two or more elements combine chemically
Can be broken into simpler substances
A process in which substances change to form new substances
Involves breaking and forming chemical bonds
A mixture where one substance dissolves into another
Example: salt dissolved in water
A substance that tastes sour and turns litmus paper red
Has a pH less than 7
A substance that tastes bitter and feels slippery
Has a pH greater than 7
A scale to measure how acidic or basic a substance is
Ranges from 0 to 14, where 7 is neutral
A connection between atoms in a molecule
Can be ionic, covalent, or metallic
A type of bond where atoms share electrons
Common in molecules like water
A type of bond formed by transfer of electrons
Occurs between metals and non-metals
A substance that allows electricity to flow when dissolved in water
Example: salt water
A solid formed in a chemical reaction that doesn't dissolve
Appears in a solution when chemicals combine
A process where electrons are lost from an atom or molecule
Often involves oxygen
A process where electrons are gained by an atom or molecule
Opposite of oxidation
A substance that speeds up a chemical reaction but is not used up
Example: enzymes in the body
A substance that dissolves other substances
Example: water is the solvent for sugar
The substance that is dissolved in a solvent
Example: sugar in water solution
Refers to compounds that contain carbon and hydrogen
Includes fuels like methane and compounds in living organisms
